node.title: 'My boss wants me back': People who lost jobs over mandates hope to return
node.description: People who lost their jobs when the vaccine mandates came into force hope to return to work soon.

node.title: British royals' Jamaica visit stirs demands for slavery reparations
node.description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate arrived in Jamaica on Tuesday as part of a week-long Caribbean tour, hours after activists protested to demand reparations for slavery amid growing scrutiny…

node.title: 'Lawful and reasonable': Employers can insist on workers being office-based
node.description: Don't expect to continue working from home if your boss wants everyone back in the office, a lawyer says. Audio

node.title: IPCA rules police shooting of Waikato man justified
node.description: The police watchdog says officers who shot and killed a man who fired at them with a military-style rifle were justified in doing so.

node.title: Airlines ask Biden to drop mask mandate and testing requirements for travelers
node.description: The CEOs of 10 U.S.-based airlines signed a letter urging President Biden to drop the requirements, as the U.K., Canada, and the European Union have already done.

node.title: Searching for Gretchen Anthony: The evidence
node.description: Investigators searching for a missing Florida mother soon realized someone was using the COVID-19 pandemic to cover up her disappearance.

node.title: Grant Robertson sets out economic plans ahead of budget
node.description: Finance Minister Grant Robertson has outlined his economic plans ahead of this year's budget, with a key focus on infrastructure, immigration and diversifying the export market.

node.title: Air NZ to bring back staff let go at start of Covid-19 pandemic
node.description: Air New Zealand has brought back 800 furloughed or former staff before the border reopens to tourists. Audio

node.title: Six people injured after shooting in Auckland's Glen Innes
node.description: Six people have been injured - two seriously - when a number of rounds were fired at a property in the Auckland suburb.

node.title: Unseasonably warm temperatures in the West to break records
node.description: Nearly 100 locations are forecast to approach or exceed record high temperatures.

node.title: Child poisoning deaths spiked during the pandemic
node.description: The first nine months of the pandemic saw a 72% jump in serious injuries related to cleaning agents, CPSC finds.

node.title: "Fearless fighter for freedom": World reacts to death of Madeleine Albright
node.description: Current and former politicians from the U.S. and abroad reacted to the news of Albright's death on Wednesday.

node.title: Stimulus checks for gas? Here's what could be coming your way.
node.description: A trio of bills in Congress would offer stimulus payments and rebates to help Americans cope with soaring gas prices.

node.title: Some unvaccinated teachers could remain barred when mandate ends
node.description: The Ministry of Education has told schools they can require Covid-19 vaccination for certain roles even after the government mandate lifts on 5 April. Audio

node.title: NZ economy in strong position though Omicron, Ukraine add uncertainty - IMF
node.description: The International Monetary Fund has given the government an approving nod for its handling of the pandemic and economy, but warned high inflation and housing affordability need to be tackled, and…

node.title: How the pandemic killed the five-day office work week
node.description: Even workers who are going back to the office will be telecommuting some of the time, and that will change downtown areas.

node.title: 'Excited', 'too late', 'free to go out': Christchurch reacts to Covid-19 changes
node.description: With vaccine mandates for many workers lifted in under two weeks and QR code scanning soon to be a thing of the past, RNZ took to the streets of Ōtautahi to find out what people thought of the…

node.title: Ukraine says 'confrontational' Russia talks moving forward as West plans more sanctions
node.description: Talks between Ukraine and Russia are confrontational but moving forward, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said on Wednesday, as the West plans to announce more sanctions against the Kremlin amid a…

node.title: Wall Street bonuses soared to record high $257,500 last year
node.description: Securities industry professionals in New York City earn roughly five times as much as other private-sector workers.

node.title: Idaho governor signs Texas-style abortion bill that would let potential family sue
node.description: The measure allows people who would have been family members to sue a doctor who performs an abortion after cardiac activity is detected in an embryo.

node.title: The limits on lawyers’ pro bono work
node.description: The Detail looks at why thousands of lawyers face restrictions on whether they can do pro bono work.

node.title: Omicron: DHBs around New Zealand grapple with health staff shortages
node.description: Nurses are the hardest hit health workers at Canterbury DHB but medical technicians, physiotherapists and lab workers are not far behind. Audio

node.title: Ukrainians fleeing Russian invasion struggle to reunite with family in U.S.
node.description: Inna Kozyar was able to escape Ukraine with her daughters. But her elderly parents are stuck in Poland and can't join them in the U.S. because they don't have visas.

node.title: Supreme Court tosses Wisconsin state maps, keeps congressional maps
node.description: Both sets of maps were drawn by Governor Tony Evers, a Democrat, and had been chosen by the state Supreme Court over those submitted by other groups.

node.title: Hillsong Church co-founder resigns after probe into inappropriate behavior
node.description: The megachurch said an internal probe into allegations of inappropriate behavior revealed that Houston "breached the Hillsong Pastor's Code of Conduct."

node.title: Instagram to allow users to view certain posts in chronological order again
node.description: Parent company Meta announced the change on Wednesday.

node.title: Mom's daily art helps strangers boost mental health
node.description: The pandemic has been a dark time for many people, but Angie Carel found a way to make it brighter not just for her family, but for thousands of strangers – using art and social media.

node.title: Madeleine Albright, first woman to serve as secretary of state, dies at 84
node.description: Albright served as the 64th U.S. secretary of state under President Bill Clinton.

node.title: Putin critic Navalny jailed in trial branded 'sham'
node.description: Alexei Navalny will be sent to a "strict regime" penal colony after a judge jailed him for nine more years.

node.title: U.S. assesses Russian forces committed "war crimes" in Ukraine
node.description: Blinken cited reports of several incidents in beseiged Mariupol.
